item.description: Click to see the cumulative final results, following all {code|friday} events for the 2020 Spring semester.

item.title: {challenge}
item.description: {challenge} The {code|friday} challenges have begun! If you complete a {c|f} Challenge, email your source code and any notes or other information to jcausey (at) astate.edu with the subject line "{code|friday} challenge". Good luck! Code_Friday/Challenge 7: Code Golf: Zig-Zag This challenge was posed by Jason Causey during the 23 September, 2016 {code|friday}, and consists of producing a repeating “Zig-Zag” pattern on the console screen while keeping the program as short as possible.

item.title: {topics}
item.description: {previous|topics} Below is a list of topics that have been discussed in previous {code|friday} meetings. This list is meant to provide inspiration for anyone wishing to do a presentation, but unsure of what kinds of topics are welcomed. It is OK to present new versions of things that are already on the “previous topics” list—especially if the topic was last discussed in a previous semester. You might also want to check out the tips and recommendations for a good presentation here.

item.title: Challenge 7: Code Golf: ZigZag
item.description:
This challenge consists of consists of producing a repeating “Zig-Zag” pattern on the console screen while keeping the program as short as possible.
Paradigm: Structured Programming
Difficulty Level: Beginner

item.title: Challenge 5: N-Queens
item.description:
This challenge consists of placing n queens on a chessboard of size n × n.
Paradigm: Structured Programming
Difficulty Level: Beginner/Intermediate

item.title: Challenge 6: Code Golf: Caesar's Cipher
item.description:
This challenge consists of encrypting and decrypting a short message using the Caesar Cipher with a selectable key.
Paradigm: Structured Programming
Difficulty Level: Intermediate

item.title: Challenge 4: Code Golf: Passwords
item.description:
This challenge consists of generating a strong 16-character password using as little code as possible.
Paradigm: Structured Programming or OOP
Difficulty Level: Beginner/Intermediate

item.title: 2014 Fall
item.description: Click to see the cumulative final results, following all {code|friday} events for the 2014 Fall semester.

item.title: Challenge 3: Peak Finding
item.description:
This challenge consists of finding all peak values in a timeseries dataset, determining some information about periodicity, and predicting the timing of future peaks.
Paradigm: Structured Programming or OOP
Difficulty Level: Beginner/Intermediate

item.title: Challenge 2: Code Golf: Checkerboard
item.description:
This challenge consists of attempting to write the shortest possible C++ program (measured in characters of source code) that will print an 8x8 grid representing a checkerboard to the screen.
Paradigm: Structured Programming>
Difficulty Level: Beginner

item.title: 2014 Spring
item.description: Click to see the cumulative final results, following all {code|friday} events for the 2014 Spring semester.

item.title: Challenge 1: Networking Headers
item.description:
This challenge was posed by Dr. Su during the 14 February, 2014 {code|friday}, and consists of a text buffering and processing challenge based on a real-world networking problem.
Paradigm: Structured Programming>
Difficulty Level: Intermediate

item.title: Presentation Tips
item.description: Although there are no strict “rules” about what you must do during a {code|friday} presentation (other than the 7-minute time limit), the following tips can make your presentation more successful and memorable: Be prepared to use the technology. The tools and technology available in the classroom is listed here. It would be a good idea to take a look at the list and make sure to use the technology to its maximum potential.

item.title: {tools|available}
item.description: Projector The projector will accept HDMI input from an external source (such as a laptop). We have adapters to many common display interfaces including DisplayPort, Mini DisplayPort, and VGA. The projector also works with the Document Camera and the room’s desktop PC (see below). You can switch between all three inputs. Document Camera The room has a document camera that can be used for displaying written (paper) material, we well as hardware projects.
